publicwhip.spmotion: *S2M-5787 Jackie Baillie: Three Cheers for Gordon Brown—That the Parliament warmly welcomes the Chancellor of the Exchequer’s Budget for 2007 and, in particular, the fact that he has frozen duty on Scotch whisky for the seventh year running; notes that this will help distillers, such as Chivas Regal, to invest in expanding production in Scotland for long-term growth; believes that excise duty stability is supporting industry competitiveness in the home market, and congratulates the Chancellor for consistently acting in the best interests of the Scotch whisky industry. Motions and amendments which have attracted additional support
S2M-5787 Three Cheers for Gordon Brown (lodged on 26 March 2007) Margaret Jamieson*, Pauline McNeill*, Helen Eadie*, Dr Elaine Murray*, Mr Kenneth Macintosh*, Bristow Muldoon*
S2M-5787 Three Cheers for Gordon Brown (lodged on 26 March 2007) Trish Godman*, Scott Barrie*, Marilyn Livingstone*

S2M-5787 Jackie Baillie: Three Cheers for Gordon Brown—That the Parliament warmly welcomes the Chancellor of the Exchequer’s Budget for 2007 and, in particular, the fact that he has frozen duty on Scotch whisky for the seventh year running; notes that this will help distillers, such as Chivas Regal, to invest in expanding production in Scotland for long-term growth; believes that excise duty stability is supporting industry competitiveness in the home market, and congratulates the Chancellor for consistently acting in the best interests of the Scotch whisky industry. Supported by: Margaret Jamieson, Pauline McNeill, Helen Eadie, Dr Elaine Murray, Mr Kenneth Macintosh, Bristow Muldoon, Trish Godman, Scott Barrie, Marilyn Livingstone Motions and amendments which have attracted additional support

S2M-5787 Jackie Baillie: Three Cheers for Gordon Brown—That the Parliament warmly welcomes the Chancellor of the Exchequer’s Budget for 2007 and, in particular, the fact that he has frozen duty on Scotch whisky for the seventh year running; notes that this will help distillers, such as Chivas Regal, to invest in expanding production in Scotland for long-term growth; believes that excise duty stability is supporting industry competitiveness in the home market, and congratulates the Chancellor for consistently acting in the best interests of the Scotch whisky industry. Supported by: Margaret Jamieson, Pauline McNeill, Helen Eadie, Dr Elaine Murray, Mr Kenneth Macintosh, Bristow Muldoon, Trish Godman, Scott Barrie, Marilyn Livingstone
